posts.post_content:
Am I correct in thinking that [Death's Shadow](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Death's Shadow)'s toughness will increase fast enough to prevent its demise if it is dealt exactly lethal damage at the same time as its controller is dealt damage?  
  
Say I have 10 life and a [Death's Shadow](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Death's Shadow), and my opponent attacks me with a [Sun Titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sun Titan) (6/6) and a [Celestial Colonnade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Celestial Colonnade) (4/4). Neither has first strike nor double strike. I block the [Sun Titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sun Titan), and my 3/3 [Death's Shadow](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Death's Shadow) is dealt 6 damage at the same time as my life is reduced to 6, upping my [Death's Shadow](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Death's Shadow)'s toughness to 7 as a state-based effect at the same time as state-based effects check for lethal amounts of damage. My [Death's Shadow](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Death's Shadow) survives.  
  
If so, that's amazing. This card just keeps getting better and better. Fantastic with cards that require payments of life as a "drawback," fantastic as a late game comeback/finisher... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Am I correct in thinking that Death's Shadow's toughness will increase fast enough to prevent its demise if it is dealt exactly lethal damage at the same time as its controller is dealt damage?

Say I have 10 life and a Death's Shadow, and my opponent attacks me with a Sun Titan (6/6) and a Celestial Colonnade (4/4). Neither has first strike nor double strike. I block the Sun Titan, and my 3/3 Death's Shadow is dealt 6 damage at the same time as my life is reduced to 6, upping my Death's Shadow's toughness to 7 as a state-based effect at the same time as state-based effects check for lethal amounts of damage. My Death's Shadow survives.

If so, that's amazing. This card just keeps getting better and better. Fantastic with cards that require payments of life as a "drawback," fantastic as a late game comeback/finisher... (see all)

posts.post_content:
Now this is a great card. It has such tempting power and immediately sends you scouring for ways to get the most out of a 13/13 for a single ![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol). The fact that this is as discussed as it is lends some credence to that idea. This is everything [Dread Slag](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dread Slag) wanted to be.

posts.post_content:
[Phyrexian Unlife](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Unlife) = you'll have a 13/13 for quite a while
  
+ [Dark Tutelage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dark Tutelage) = make it larger than 13/13 even (see rulings)
  
   
Also, Mom[entous Fall](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=entous Fall) this always bring you back up to 13 life, while drawing you 13+ cards when you have Phyrexian Unlife in play.

posts.post_content:
If you have negative life, does it get +X/+X? Seems like it would, but just wanted to check.  
  
Edit: Looked this up. I think it does add it, see last line of rule below:  
107.1b Most of the time, the \_Magic\_ game uses only positive numbers and zero. You can't choose a negative number, deal negative damage, gain negative life, and so on. However, it's possible for a game value, such as a creature's power, to be less than zero. If a calculation or comparison that would determine the result of an effect needs to use a negative value, it does so. If such a calculation yields a negative number, zero is used instead, unless that effect sets a player's life total to a specific value, sets a creature's power or toughness to a specific value, or otherwise modifies a creature's power or toughness.  
  
2nd Edit: And from the worldwake FAQ making it official:  
  
\* If your life total is less than 0 and an effect (such as the one from an opponent's Abyssal Persecutor) is keeping you from losing the game... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
If you have negative life, does it get +X/+X? Seems like it would, but just wanted to check.

Edit: Looked this up. I think it does add it, see last line of rule below:
107.1b Most of the time, the _Magic_ game uses only positive numbers and zero. You can't choose a negative number, deal negative damage, gain negative life, and so on. However, it's possible for a game value, such as a creature's power, to be less than zero. If a calculation or comparison that would determine the result of an effect needs to use a negative value, it does so. If such a calculation yields a negative number, zero is used instead, unless that effect sets a player's life total to a specific value, sets a creature's power or toughness to a specific value, or otherwise modifies a creature's power or toughness.

2nd Edit: And from the worldwake FAQ making it official:

* If your life total is less than 0 and an effect (such as the one from an opponent's Abyssal Persecutor) is keeping you from losing the game... (see all)

posts.post_content: @Zulp Personally, not really. It's flavour is summed up with the title: Death's Shadow. It grows stronger the closer to death you are. Now, it may be dubious flavour that your death's shadow is fighting FOR you, but having it based off an opponent's life total would probably make a rules nightmare ;-)
